newsitem.title: USA: U.S. spot natgas mostly steady, up in West on heat.
newsitem.headline: U.S. spot natgas mostly steady, up in West on heat.

text.p: U.S. spot gas prices were mostly steady Thursday as the market's focus shifted toward the West, where storage was well below year-ago and weather remained hot after reaching record levels earlier in the week.
Prices in the Permian basin rose by about two cents to the high-$1.60s to mid-$1.70s. Late deals were reported done as high as $1.78 per mmBtu.
Similarly at the southern California border prices were talked in a wide range of $1.78 to $1.90, up an average of five cents from Wednesday.
Temperatures in southern California have dropped slightly to the 80s, Weather Services Corp said, but temperatures in Arizona remain in the 90s.
WSC is calling for temperatures to be 12-22 degrees above normal this weekend in the Southwest, followed by slightly cooler temperatures early next week.
American Gas Association said Wednesday gas stocks in the West region were down two bcf last week to 163 bcf, or 34 percent of capacity, compared with 482 bcf a year ago.
Also supporting the market was the extended shutdown of the 1,070 megawatt San Onofre 2 nuclear unit in southern California.
Edison International said late Wednesday the unit would not restart Thursday as previously expected due to a small leak in a valve. The company could not comment on when it would restart.
On the East Coast, where temperatures are climbing, New York city-gate prices drifted about five cents lower to $2.20-2.27.
Despite early talk of softening prior to the NYMEX open, Louisiana Gulf prices for the most part held in the mid-$1.80s per mmBtu, with Henry Hub again quoted at $1.86-1.88.
Gulf cash remained in convergence with NYMEX Henry Hub April natgas, which fell 1.1 cents to $1.885 at 1325 EST.
In south Texas, prices were also steady in the low-$1.80s amid warmer weather. However, cooler weather was forecast for early next week across the state.
In the Midcontinent, prices were little changed at $1.73-1.75, with Demarcation quoted mostly in the mid-$1.70s.
Chicago city-gate values were a little softer around $1.94.
Temperatures throughout the Midwest are forecast to climb to much above-normal levels Friday but then settle to near-normal by the weekend.
